negotiation:
Helen said in round 1: 
Hi everyone, given the rules of this game, if we all guess rationally, we will all choose 0 and end up splitting the reward 10 ways. I propose we coordinate and all choose the number 33 instead. This way, 2/3 of the average will be about 22, and we'll all be equal distance from the target, ensuring we split the reward evenly and fairly. Let me know if you agree to this plan.

Alice replied in round 1: Helen, your proposal is interesting. If we all choose 33, then 2/3 of the average would indeed be about 22, and we would likely end up splitting the reward. 

However, there is a strong incentive for individual players to defect and choose a lower number to try to be closest to the 2/3 average, especially if they suspect others may do the same. There is no way to enforce coordination.

Given the competitive nature of this game, I believe the equilibrium is for everyone to guess 0, as you initially pointed out. Any cooperation is likely unstable.

I'm inclined to go with the rational choice of 0, as I expect that's what most players will do. But I appreciate you starting this discussion and exploring cooperative solutions, even if I suspect they won't work in this case.

Jack replied in round 1: 
I agree with Alice's analysis. While cooperation to all choose 33 could lead to a higher average payout, there is a strong incentive to cheat and choose a lower number. In a one-shot game with no ability to enforce agreements, the rational choice for each player is to assume others will guess low numbers, making 0 the equilibrium guess.

Helen, I appreciate you exploring a cooperative solution, but given the rules of this particular game, I think we will all end up guessing 0 or very low numbers. The competitive dynamics make cooperation unlikely to emerge, so pursuing the rational equilibrium is the safest approach.

Ivy replied in round 1: 
I agree with the points made by Alice and Jack. As much as I appreciate Helen's attempt to coordinate on a cooperative solution, I don't believe it is stable in this particular game setup.

With everyone choosing independently and the incentive to be closest to 2/3 of the average, there is simply too much temptation to defect and choose a lower number than any agreed upon value. We have no way to enforce cooperation.

Therefore, I believe we will inevitably converge to an equilibrium where everyone chooses 0 (or very low numbers), as this is the rational unilateral choice when anticipating competitive behavior from others. 

While a cooperative outcome is preferable, the dynamics of this game make it unlikely. I plan to go with the equilibrium strategy and choose 0. Apologies Helen, and thanks for trying to find a collaborative approach, even if it was not to be in this case.

Frank replied in round 1: 
I appreciate everyone's thoughtful analysis of the game dynamics. I agree that Helen's cooperative solution is appealing in theory, but unlikely to be stable in practice given the strong incentives for individual players to defect to a lower number.

As Alice, Jack and Ivy have persuasively argued, the rational equilibrium is for everyone to guess 0 or very low numbers. With no way to enforce cooperation, we are likely to end up in a competitive race to the bottom.

In an ideal world, we would coordinate and split the reward. But I believe the rules of this particular game make that infeasible. I will follow the sound logic of the group and also choose 0 as the rational unilateral action.

Thanks Helen for exploring creative solutions, and to everyone else for the insightful discussion of the underlying game theory. While it's a pity we can't cooperate, I think we've reached the strategically optimal outcome given the challenging circumstances.

Grace said in round 1: 
Hi everyone, 
To maximize our chances of winning this game, we should all guess low numbers. If everyone guesses a low number, the average will be low, and 2/3 of a low average will be an even lower number. 

Therefore, I propose we all agree to guess numbers between 0-10. That way, the average will likely be under 10, and 2/3 of that average will be a very low number around 0-7. If we all guess in that 0-7 range, it improves the odds that one of us will win.

What does everyone think? Can we agree to keep our guesses between 0-10 to keep the overall average and target number low? Let me know if you're on board with this strategy.
Bob replied in round 1: 
I appreciate the proposal, but I don't think everyone agreeing to guess low numbers is the optimal strategy. Here's why:

If we all guess low numbers between 0-10, then you're right that the average will be low and 2/3 of that average will be even lower, likely between 0-7. However, if everyone is aiming for that 0-7 range, it actually becomes very difficult to guess closest to the 2/3 average, since we'll all be clustered together.

I think a better approach is for each person to simply guess 0 or 1. If everyone guesses 0 or 1, then the average will be 0.5 at most. Two-thirds of 0.5 is 0.33. So the winning guess would be 0. 

By everyone guessing the lowest possible numbers (0 or 1), we simplify the game and make 0 the clear best guess to win. There's no need to coordinate a range - if we all just guess 0 or 1, someone guessing 0 is guaranteed to win.

That's the approach I recommend for maximizing the group's chances of someone winning. Let me know what you think!
Cindy replied in round 1: 
I see the merits of both proposals, but I slightly favor Bob's approach of everyone guessing either 0 or 1 for a few reasons:

1. It's simpler. We don't need to coordinate a range, just the lowest two possible guesses. 

2. If everyone goes with 0 or 1, the average will be 0.5 at most, and 2/3 of that is 0.33. So guessing 0 is guaranteed to be closest to the target value.

3. If we agree on a range like 0-10, people may still guess on the higher end of that range, pushing the average up. Sticking to just 0 and 1 prevents that.

So in the interest of simplicity and guaranteeing a win for someone guessing 0, I think we should all commit to guessing either 0 or 1. 

Bob, thanks for the smart proposal. And thanks Grace for getting the discussion started! Let me know if anyone has concerns with the 0 or 1 approach.
Jack replied in round 1: 
I agree with Bob and Cindy's reasoning that everyone guessing either 0 or 1 is the optimal strategy to ensure someone in the group wins. It removes any uncertainty around what numbers people might choose within an agreed upon range.

If we all commit to guessing the minimum possible values, the average will be as low as it can be - 0.5 at most. And 2/3 of 0.5 is 0.33, so 0 will clearly be the closest guess to the target value.

I think rallying around the 0 or 1 strategy is our best bet. We keep it simple, we minimize the average, and we guarantee that someone who guesses 0 will win for the group. I'm on board with this approach if everyone else is as well.

Please speak up if you have any concerns, but I believe committing as a group to all guess 0 or 1 is the way to go. Let's lock that in as our plan.
Frank replied in round 1: 
I appreciate everyone's input and analysis on this. After considering the options, I agree that the optimal strategy is for all of us to commit to guessing either 0 or 1. 

As Bob, Cindy and Jack have laid out, if we all guess 0 or 1, the average will be 0.5 at most, and 2/3 of that is 0.33. So anyone who guesses 0 is guaranteed to have the closest guess and win.

Trying to coordinate guesses within a range like 0-10 leaves too much room for variation and uncertainty. Committing to just the two lowest options keeps things clear and simple.

So I'm fully on board with the plan for all of us to guess either 0 or 1. As long as we all stick to that, someone guessing 0 is sure to win for the team. 

Unless anyone has any final objections, I say we lock this in as our agreed upon strategy. Thanks everyone for the good teamwork and strategic thinking!
